channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Hard Times in Venezuela Breed Malaria as Desperate Flock to Mines
item.media:description: Carlos Raphael, right, and his crew in July, mining for gold at the Cuatro Muertos, or Four Dead Men, an illegal mine near Las Claritas, Venezuela, that is 15 stories deep.
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.description: Many turn to panning for black-market gold in the watery pits of mines, where mosquitoes infect them. Once they return home to recover, the disease spreads.
item.dc:creator: NICHOLAS CASEY

item.title: Rio ‘Has Never Felt So Safe.’ But What Happens After the Games?
item.media:description: A police operation last week in Vila do João, part of Maré, a large area of favelas, during the Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro.
item.description: Brazil has deployed a security force of 85,000 for the Olympics, but with an economy in turmoil, residents fear that violence will soon surge again.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO and ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Once Unthinkable, More British Jews Seek German Citizenship
item.media:description: Philip Levine, center, a Londoner, has decided to apply for German citizenship, which would allow him to obtain a passport to travel, live or work in the European Union despite the British vote to leave the bloc.
item.media:credit: Conor O'Leary for The New York Times
item.description: A desire to retain the right to live and work on the Continent leads some in Britain to explore ways to gain a second passport after the Brexit vote.
item.dc:creator: KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA

item.title: Valtice Journal: How Czech Wine Got Its Terroir Back
item.media:description: At the center of the Moravian wine industry is Valtice, a small Czech town along the border with Austria. Valtice is surrounded by hills lined with neatly groomed vineyards.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: Centuries of winemaking expertise, almost lost under Communist rule, are once again making the Valtice region of South Moravia a destination for wine connoisseurs.
item.dc:creator: HANA de GOEIJ

item.title: Boko Haram Video Appears to Show Bodies of Kidnapped Girls
item.media:description: An image from a video released by Boko Haram that purports to show several of the schoolgirls who were kidnapped from Chibok in 2014.
item.description: A masked, camouflaged fighter who appears in video said many of the abducted girls had died in Nigerian military airstrikes.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Hong Kong Protest Leaders Sentenced to Community Service
item.description: The activists Joshua Wong and Nathan Law were spared jail in a 2014 protest that led to pro-democracy sit-ins, and a third defendant’s jail term was suspended.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY and CHARLOTTE YANG

item.title: Afghanistan Forces Struggle to Hold Firm Against Taliban in South
item.media:description: Afghan security personnel prepared for combat with Taliban militants in the Nad Ali district of Helmand on August 10.
item.description: Elite forces are trying to hold their ground near Lashkar Gah, the capital of Helmand Province and a critical link in the defense of the region.
item.dc:creator: MUJIB MASHAL

item.title: Under Pressure Over Aleppo Siege, Russia Hints at Seeking Deal with U.S.
item.media:description: Smoke rises from burning tires, which activists said are used to create smoke cover from warplanes, in Aleppo, Syria on Aug. 1.
item.description: Russia’s foreign minister acknowledged that daily three-hour pauses in fighting in Aleppo were insufficient to halt a humanitarian disaster.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE and ALISON SMALE
item.category: International Committee of the Red Cross

item.title: Bombing of Doctors Without Borders Hospital in Yemen Kills at Least 15
item.media:description: A body at the site of an airstrike on Monday at Abs Hospital in Yemen’s northern Hajjah Province.
item.description: The bombing in northern Yemen came two days after airstrikes by Saudi warplanes killed at least 19 people, mostly children.
item.dc:creator: SHUAIB ALMOSAWA and ROD NORDLAND
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: Russia and Ukraine Tensions Rise Over a Raid That May Not Have Happened
item.media:description: A Ukrainian soldier at his position on the front line near Donetsk, Ukraine, last week.
item.description: Russian officials said two soldiers died in a skirmish in Crimea that Ukraine denied as Germany’s foreign minister appealed to Moscow to reduce tensions.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Sinosphere: China Faces a Surge in Cardiovascular Disease, Study Finds
item.media:description: Men smoking on a Beijing street. More than half of Chinese men smoke, a factor in rising cardiovascular disease, along with other lifestyle factors such as changing diet and less physical activity.
item.description: The nation’s embrace of Western foods like red meat and soda has exacerbated the problem, researchers from Harvard University found.
item.dc:creator: JAVIER C. HERNÁNDEZ
item.category: Journal of the American College of Cardiology

item.title: President of Zambia Wins Narrow Victory as Rival Calls for Recount
item.media:description: Hundreds of people lined up to vote at Kanyama Basic School for the general election on Thursday in Lusaka, Zambia.
item.description: Edgar Lungu won another slim election victory over his main rival, Hakainde Hichilema, after an unusually violent campaign for the country.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Sinosphere: Chinese Court Upholds Ruling Against Historian Who Questioned Tale of Wartime Heroes
item.media:description: The historian Hong Zhenkuai, left, with a local guide, on his way to Little Lotus Peak on Langya Mountain, where the Chinese government says five Communist soldiers chose to jump rather than surrender to the Japanese invaders in 1941.
item.description: The decision, over a story about five Communist soldiers said to have fended off Japanese troops during World War II, continues a crackdown on dissenting views.
item.dc:creator: KIKI ZHAO

item.title: Istanbul Police Detain 136 Courthouse Staff
item.description: Police officers apprehended 136 people working at three Istanbul courthouses on Monday as part of an investigation into the July 15 abortive coup.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Unlikely Facebook Friendship Saves Afghan Baby With Heart Defect
item.media:description: Doctors prepared Yehia, who was born with several congenital heart defects, for surgery at the Wolfson Medical Center on July 31 in Holon, near Tel Aviv.
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.description: Two digital acquaintances, one in Israel and another in Afghanistan, collaborated to save a baby in Pakistan with life-threatening congenital heart problems.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Secret Ledger in Ukraine Lists Cash for Donald Trump’s Campaign Chief
item.media:description: Paul Manafort, Donald J. Trump’s campaign chairman, ran a political consulting operation out of a first-floor office on Sofiivska Street in Kiev, Ukraine.
item.media:credit: Joseph Sywenkyj for The New York Times
item.description: An examination of the activities of Paul Manafort shows how he benefited from powerful interests that are now under scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER, MIKE McINTIRE and BARRY MEIER

item.title: Rio de Janeiro Journal: Celebrity Chefs Turn Wasted Olympics Food Into Meals for Homeless
item.media:description: The Refettorio Gastromotiva, a dining hall for homeless people that the Italian chef Massimo Bottura helped open in the downtrodden Lapa neighborhood of Rio de Janeiro.
item.media:credit: Dado Galdieri for The New York Times
item.description: With donated ingredients and some of the world’s top chefs, Refettorio Gastromotiva has become a feel-good counterpoint to the commercialization of the Games.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW JACOBS

item.title: Hey Ho, It’s Old: England Embraces Punk Rock 40 Years Later
item.media:description: Joey Ramone, left, and Dee Dee Ramone at the Roundhouse in London on July 4, 1976.
item.description: Some fans are less than thrilled by an institutional tribute to the summer of 1976, when the Ramones and the Sex Pistols helped punk rock take flight.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER D. SHEA

item.title: Sinosphere: A Writer’s Quest to Unearth the Roots of Tibet’s Unrest
item.media:description: On March 10, 1959, several thousand Tibetans, fearing that the Chinese might abduct the Dalai Lama, gathered at the Norbulingka summer palace to protect the Tibetan spiritual leader.
item.media:credit: The Office of Tibet, Washington, D.C.
item.description: Jianglin Li examines recent Tibetan protests against Chinese rule against the backdrop of the military campaigns and repression of the 1950s.
item.dc:creator: LUO SILING

item.title: Ryan Lochte and Three Teammates Robbed at Gunpoint
item.media:description: Ryan Lochte, left, was one of four American swimmers robbed in Rio de Janeiro.
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.description: The swimmers’ taxi was stopped by men posing as police officers, the U.S. Olympic Committee said, although Lochte had initially denied the incident.
item.dc:creator: REBECCA R. RUIZ and VICTOR MATHER

item.title: Fighting Rages in Aleppo, Syria, Killing Dozens of Civilians
item.description: The civilian death toll in Aleppo Province over the past two weeks rose to at least 327, a third of them women and children, a monitoring group said.
item.dc:creator: HWAIDA SAAD and ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Network Led by One Individual Carried Out Bombings, Thai Official Says
item.media:description: Patrolling on Sunday near the Erawan Shrine, in Bangkok, the site of a fatal blast last year. On Thursday and Friday, a series of bombings in five Thai provinces, killed four people and injured dozens.
item.description: A deputy national police chief declined to identify the perpetrators, but noted that evidence from all of last week’s attack scenes was linked.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK

item.title: Kenny Baker, the R2-D2 Robot in ‘Star Wars,’ Dies at 81
item.media:description: Kenny Baker, who played R2-D2 in six “Star Wars” films, in 2001 in Lake Buena Vista, Fla.
item.description: R2-D2 so changed Mr. Baker’s career that in later years he told an interviewer that if he could go back in time, he would do it again for free.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: Botched Restoration of Fresco in Spain Inspires a Comic Opera
item.media:description: The altered “Ecce Homo” fresco, by the painter Elías García Martínez, displayed in Borja, Spain, in 2012.
item.description: Two Americans wrote the work, “Behold the Man,” which tells how amateurish repairs to a painting of Jesus in 2012 brought a tourist bonanza to a struggling town.
item.dc:creator: DOREEN CARVAJAL

item.title: Snapchat Finds Itself on the Wrong Side of a Racial Lens. Again.
item.media:description: Snapchat says this filter is inspired by anime, but some observers say it’s racially insensitive.
item.description: A lens that gave users slanted eyes was criticized as an Asian caricature. It wasn’t the first time the app has faced a backlash.
item.dc:creator: KATIE ROGERS

item.title: What in the World: Flocking to Robben Island: Tourists by Day, Poachers by Night
item.media:description: The former penal colony of Robben Island, South Africa, with Cape Town in the background.
item.description: The fall of apartheid emptied the South African island’s infamous cellblocks. Now a global appetite for abalone is emptying its shellfish beds.
item.dc:creator: NORIMITSU ONISHI

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: Brazil’s Uplifting Olympics
item.media:description: Residents of Mangueira, a favela in Rio de Janeiro, watched the opening ceremony of the Olympic Games on Aug. 5.
item.description: Why is it the developed world has to find fault in a developing country that organizes a major sporting event?
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Editorial: What Two Years of Negative Interest Rates in Europe Tell Us
item.description: Pushing down the cost of borrowing doesn’t address weak consumer demand or weak business investment.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Editorial: A Looming Clash in Venezuela
item.media:description: A protester wore a sticker that read “recall now,” during a demonstration last month in Caracas, Venezuela.
item.description: Regional leaders must take sides in a fight over the timing of a referendum that could oust President Nicolás Maduro.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Talking to Terrorists
item.media:description: Harry Sarfo, a former Islamic State fighter from Germany, inside the maximum-security prison in Bremen where he is serving a three-year sentence on terrorism charges.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: For once, the conversation wasn’t via social media, and the name the Islamic State defector used was the one on his birth certificate.
item.dc:creator: RUKMINI CALLIMACHI
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Outstanding Issues: A Yemeni Teenager’s Trip to Estonia, by Way of Guantánamo
item.media:description: Ahmed Abdul Qader, a former Guantánamo Bay detainee, at Freedom Square in Tallinn, Estonia, in May.
item.media:credit: Adam Ferguson for The New York Times
item.description: The reporter Charlie Savage wrote about an ex-Guantánamo inmate’s resettlement; the story didn’t end when the article published.
item.dc:creator: CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: At the Front in a Scarred Falluja
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.description: Bryan Denton, a photographer who works for The New York Times and is based in Beirut, Lebanon, gives his account of covering Iraqi forces’ recapture of Falluja from the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: BRYAN DENTON
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Devanampattinam Journal: Mortal to Divine and Back: India’s Transgender Goddesses
item.description: During the 10-day Hindu festival Mayana Kollai, the troubles of transgender women are distant as they transform into the deities they worship and are revered by villagers.
item.dc:creator: Photographs by CANDACE FEIT
